newsitem.title: UK: GEC may face revolt over "fat cat" pay deal.
newsitem.headline: GEC may face revolt over "fat cat" pay deal.

text.p: A fresh row has erupted over "fat cat" pay in Britain after General Electric Company Plc revealed a multimillion pound pay and bonus package for its new managing director George Simpson.

The defence and engineering group now faces a potential revolt by institutional shareholders angered by Simpson's contract, estimated to pay him 10 million pounds ($15.60 million) over the next five years.
Investor Norwich Union said on Thursday it had not discarded the possibility of voting against Simpson's appointment at the company's annual meeting on September 6.
Mutually-owned investment institution Norwich is concerned that performance criteria Simpson has to meet to receive a huge block of share options are not tough enough.

"We're clearly concerned as things stand at present mainly about the performance criteria attached to the share options," a Norwich spokeswoman said. "They are not challenging enough, in our view they're just too easy."

Simpson would receive the options if GEC's share price beat the FTSE 100 index by 10 percent in any six months within a specified three-year period. This effectively means he would receive them even if GEC's shares outperformed only briefly.
Simpson, former chief executive of Lucas Industries who takes over at GEC from Lord Weinstock, has already been dubbed "the fattest cat of all" by British newspapers.
His three-year contract includes annual pay of up to 1.5 million pounds, including pension contributions, plus a complicated package of share options.
Simpson's controversial deal has turned up the heat in the debate about top executives' pay sparked last year when former British Gas chief executive Cedric Brown was awarded a 75 percent pay rise.

Mounting public anger over fat cat salaries prompted the government to set up a committee to curb boardroom excesses. But despite guidelines set out by the committee, led by Sir Richard Greenbury, chairman of retailer Marks and Spencer Plc, executive salaries continue to rise.

Earlier this month Robert Diamond, new head of global markets at investment bank Barclays de Zoete Wedd, was reported to have signed a two-year contract worth at least 5 million pounds, plus a range of incentive payments.

And British cider-maker Matthew Clark made headlines when it payed nearly 430,000 pounds to its chairman Peter Aikens for moving from Guildford to Bristol, the equivalent of 4,000 pounds a mile. ($1=0.6412 pounds)
